content.title: Dry Mouth
content.description:
General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Rinse mouth with either: tap water or saline (salt water) or bicarbonate rinses (½ tsp. baking soda dissolved in 2 cups of water)
  • Use sugarless lozenges and gums
  • Use of mouthwashes containing anti-microbial proteins to reduce cavities
  • Avoid caffeine, antihistamines, decongestants
  • Avoid mouthwashes containing alcohol
  • Use saliva substitutes:
    • Oral Balance – sugar-free long-lasting lubricant
    • Salivart– aerosol spray oral moisturizer
    • Biotenetoothpaste, oral rinse, gum, gel, mouthspray

content.title: Anesthesiologist
content.description: A doctor who administers anesthesia for patients undergoing surgical, obstetrical, diagnostic, or therapeutic procedures while monitoring the patient’s condition and supporting vital organ functions. They also diagnose and treat acute, chronic and/or cancer pain as well as provide resuscitation and medical management for patients with critical illnesses and severe injuries.

content.title: Cardiologist
content.description: An internal medicine doctor specializing in cardiovascular disease, which involves intricate technical procedures to evaluate heart rhythms and determining appropriate treatment.

content.title: Colon and Rectal Surgeon
content.description: A doctor who diagnoses and treats various diseases of the small intestine, colon, rectum anal canal, and perianal area including the organs and tissues related with primary intestinal diseases (liver, urinary, and female reproductive system). They treat conditions such as hemorrhoids, fissures (painful tears in the anal lining), abscesses and fistulas (infections located around the anus and rectum). They also diagnose and treat problem of the intestines and colon such as cancer, polyps (precancerous growths), and inflammatory conditions.

content.title: Family Medicine Physicians
content.description: Personal doctors, also called family practice doctors, who deliver a range of acute, chronic, and preventive medical care services to individuals of all ages, families and communities. In addition to diagnosing and treating illness, they also provide preventive care including routine checkups, health-risk assessments, immunization and screening tests, and personalized counseling on maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Family physicians also manage chronic illness, often coordinating care provided by other specialists.

content.title: Gastroenterologist (GI)
content.description: An internist specialized in diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the digestive organs including the stomach, bowels, liver and gallbladder. This doctor treats conditions such as abdominal pain, ulcers, diarrhea, cancer, and jaundice and performs complex diagnostic and therapeutic procedures using endoscopes to visualize internal organs.

content.title: Internist or Doctor of Internal Medicine
content.description: A personal doctor who provides long-term, comprehensive care in the office and in the hospital, managing both common and complex illnesses of adolescent, adults and the elderly. Internists are trained in the diagnosis and treatment of cancer, infections, and diseases affecting the heart, blood, kidneys, and joints as well as the digestive, respiratory and vascular systems. They are also trained in the essentials of primary care and internal medicine, incorporating an understanding of disease prevention, wellness, substance abuse, mental health, and effective treatment of common problems of the eyes, ears, skin, nervous system, and reproductive organs.

content.title: Medical Oncologist
content.description: An internal medicine doctor specialized in the diagnosis and treatment of all types of cancer and other benign and malignant tumors. This specialist decides on and administers therapy for these malignancies, as well as consults with surgeons and radiotherapists on other treatments for cancer.

content.title: Obstetrician, Gynecologist and OB-GYN
content.description: Doctors who focus on the health of women before, during and after childbearing years, diagnosing and treating conditions of the reproductive system and associated disorders. Some gynecologists specialize in oncology and are called Gynecologic Oncologists. They provide consultation and comprehensive management for patients with gynecologic cancer and resulting complications, including diagnostic and therapeutic procedures.

content.title: Otolaryngologist (Ear, Nose and Throat or ENT) and Head and Neck Surgeon
content.description: Doctors who provide medical and/or surgical therapy for the prevention of diseases, allergies, neoplasms (cancers), deformities, disorders and/or injuries of the ears, nose, sinuses, throat, respiratory, and upper alimentary systems, face, jaws, and other head and neck systems. Head and neck oncology, facial, plastic, and reconstructive surgery and the treatment of disorders of hearing and voice are fundamental areas of expertise. Some specialize in Plastic Surgery within the Head and Neck and perform plastic and reconstructive procedures within the head, face, neck, and associated structures, including cutaneous head and neck oncology and reconstruction, management of maxillofacial trauma, soft tissue repair and cosmetic surgery.

content.title: Pathologist
content.description: A doctor who deals with the causes and nature of disease. Contributes to diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment through knowledge gained by the laboratory application of the biologic, chemical, and physical sciences. They use information gathered from the microscopic examination of tissue specimens, cell and body fluid, and from clinical laboratory tests on body fluids and secretions for the diagnosis, exclusion and monitoring of disease.

content.title: Plastic Surgeon
content.description: A doctor who deals with the repair, reconstruction, or replacement of physical defects of form or function involving skin, musculoskeletal system, craniomaxillofacial structures, hand, extremities, breast and trunk, and external genitalia or cosmetic enhancement of these areas of the body. The plastic surgeon uses cosmetic surgical principles to both improve overall appearance and to optimize the outcome of reconstructive procedures.

content.title: Pulmonologist
content.description: An internist who treats diseases of the lungs and airways. This specialist diagnoses and treats cancer, pneumonia, pleurisy, asthma, occupational and environmental diseases, bronchitis, sleep disorders, emphysema and other complex disorders of the lungs.

content.title: Radiologist
content.description: A doctor who specializes in imaging techniques to diagnose, manage and treat a wide spectrum of diseases. Radiologists called Diagnostic Radiologists use X-rays, radionuclides, ultrasound, and electromagnetic radiation to diagnose and treat disease. Others who are called Interventional Radiologists combine competence in imaging, image-guided minimally invasive procedures, and peri-procedural patient care to diagnose and treat benign and malignant condition of the body. Therapies include embolization, angioplasty, stent placement, thrombus management, drainage, and ablation among others. An additional specialty called Radiation Oncologists uses ionizing radiation and other modalities to treat malignant and some benign diseases. They may also use computed tomography (CT) scans, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), ultrasound, and hyperthermia (heat) as additional modalities to aid in treatment planning and delivery.

content.title: Surgeon or General Surgeon
content.description: A doctor with expertise in the diagnosis and care of patients with diseases and disorders affecting the abdomen, digestive tract, endocrine system, breast, skin, and blood vessels. They are also trained in the treatment of patients who are injured or critically ill, and in the care of pediatric and cancer patients. Surgeons are skilled in the use of minimally invasive techniques and endoscopies.  Common conditions treated by general surgeons include hernias, gallstones, appendicitis, breast tumors, thyroid disorders, pancreatitis, bowel obstructions, colon inflammations, and colon cancer. They operate on the body to treat injuries or disorders through an incision or with other instruments. Another group called Thoracic Surgeons are doctors with expertise and training that encompasses the operative, perioperative, and surgical critical care of patients with acquired and congenital pathologic conditions within the chest. They treat diseased or injured organs in the chest, including the esophagus (muscular tube that passes food to the stomach), trachea (windpipe), pleura (membranes that cover and protect the lung), mediastinum (area separating the left and right lungs that contains the heart), chest wall, diaphragm (separates the chest from abdomen), pericardium (membrane covering the heart), heart (including the pericardium, coronary arteries, valves and myocardium), and lungs. The most common diseases requiring a thoracic surgeon include heart lesions, such as coronary artery disease and valve problems, lung cancer, chest trauma, esophageal cancer, emphysema, and heart and lung transplantation.

content.title: Urologist (Genitourinary Surgeon)
content.description: A doctor who focus on diagnosing and treating disorders of the urinary system of males and females, and on the reproductive system of males. This specialist manages non-surgical problems such as urinary tract infections and benign prostatic hyperplasia, as well as surgical problems such as the surgical management of cancers, the correction of congenital abnormalities, and correcting stress incontinence.

content.title: Constipation
content.description:
Call physician immediately for:  

  • No bowel movement in 2-3 days
  • Constipation that doesn’t respond to prescriptions taken as ordered
  • History of diverticulitis and fever
  • Inability to pass gas

General helpful suggestions and interventions: 

  • Take stool softeners/laxatives as prescribed on a routine basis, do not wait until constipation occurs
  • Increase fluids to include at least 8 glasses of fluid daily
    • Prune juice, warmed juices or ciders, decaffeinated teas, hot lemonade
    • Milk or milk products should be minimized if these prove constipating
    • Hot beverages prior to attempting defecation may stimulate evacuation
    • Limit caffeinated drinks and alcohol because they act as diuretics (causing dehydration)
  • Establish a regular time for daily bowel movement; after breakfast is ideal, when the contractions in the intestines are the strongest
    • Increase time and privacy for toileting
  • Eat foods high in fiber such as:
    • Fruits with peels (apples, pears), prunes, orange, raisins, strawberries, blueberries
    • Vegetables – corn, broccoli, brussels sprouts, potato with skin, green peas, carrots
    • Wheat bran
    • Oatmeal
    • Whole-grain breads – look for 100% whole wheat, rye, oat or bran as the 1st or 2nd ingredient
    • New grains such as barley, oats, faro, kamut, quinoa
    • Beans and legumes
    • Brown rice and wild rice rather than white
    • Popcorn
    • Peanut butter
  • Other foods and drinks to help manage constipation:
    • Senna tea, Smooth Moves
  • Trail mix with dried fruit, raisins, nuts, and sunflower seeds
  • Bowl of oatmeal with berries and wheat germ 
    • Warm lentil or black bean soup
  • Avoid foods and products that may contribute to constipation:
    • Milk and dairy foods, such as ice cream, sour cream, and cheese
    • Alcohol
    • Gas forming foods such as broccoli, cabbage, carbonated beverages, chewing gum and drinking with straws
  • Establish a daily exercise routine to tolerance

Fatigue
content.description:
General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • If you are not getting enough sleep or if sleep is interrupted:
    • Limit time in bed to actual sleep time
    • Avoid long or late afternoon naps
    • Establish a routine time for going to sleep each night and waking each morning
    • Establish a routine before going to sleep, for example keep an hour to relax prior to going to sleep. Do not watch any TV programs or read books that are overly stimulating during this hour.
    • Limit caffeine and alcohol intake
    • If other symptoms are disturbing your sleep, speak to your physician for prescriptions, recommendations for relief of those symptoms
    • If you are still having difficulty in getting enough sleep after trying all of the above, speak with your physician about considering a sleep aid
  • Moderate activity 3-5 hours a week (or more if tolerated) may help your fatigue
    • You may need to start with light activity for short periods of time and build up to more exercise little by little
    • Ask your health team to help you plan the best time and place for activity and how long and often to exercise
    • Choose activities that are pleasing to you, balance exercise and non-strenuous activities (such as, reading, puzzles, listening to music, doing a hobby, having talks/visits with family and friends)
    • Exercises such as tai chi and yoga may help relieve fatigue as they combine activities like movement, stretching, balance, and controlled breathing
    • Activities such as walking and going outdoors have been shown to help patients with fatigue to feel better and have more energy
    • A program of regular times for activity and rest will help to make the most your energy and help promote sleep at night
    • Prioritize your daily schedule
  • If you are not eating and drinking enough fluids each day, this may add to your fatigue. Speak to your case manager and/or physician for recommendations for your loss of appetite.
  • If you are feeling anxious or fearful about your condition or are you feeling depressed or troubled, or have lost interest in people or things, tell your case manager and/or physician who can make some recommendations to help you through these difficult feelings.

content.title: Diarrhea
content.description:
Call physician immediately for any of the following:

  • Increase of 7 or more stools each day over usual
  • Not able to hold stools, urgent use of bathroom
  • Severe cramping
  • Bloody stools
  • OR any of the above that continues for 24 hours even after taking medication for diarrhea
  • OR signs of dehydration even after you follow the management recommendations on the next page and follow doctor’s orders
    • Signs of dehydration are - increased thirst, dry mouth, swollen tongue, weakness, dizziness, decreased urine output, fever, palpitations, confusion, fainting
  • Temperature above 100.4F (38C)
  • Diarrhea with not much intake for more than 24 hours
  • Weight loss of more than 5 pounds since diarrhea started
  • If you have a colostomy– a severe increase in ostomy output as compared to usual that is limiting your self-care or activities of daily living

General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Monitor temperature daily and call physician for fever greater than 100.4 F (38 C)
  • Replace fluid loss with one cup of fluid for each diarrhea episode
  • Drink 8 to 12 cups of clear liquid per day, such as water, plain broth or bouillon, diluted cranberry juice, sports drinks, decaffeinated tea or coffee, coconut water, chamomile and ginger tea, ginger ale, rice milk; and diluted fruit juices and nectars, such as peach, pear, mango, or papaya nectar (avoid grape and prune juices)
  • Try clove tea, which may lessen severity of diarrhea
  • Eat foods high in soluble fiber such as a BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast), skinned turkey, skinned chicken, cream of rice cereal, plain unsweetened graham crackers, canned fruit without the skins, such as peaches and pears
  • Consider foods such as: cooked beets, peeled apples, baked potatoes without skin, white bread, plain pasta, avocadoes, and asparagus tips
  • Cook all vegetables well as raw vegetables are hard to digest
  • Eat foods at room temperature as hot and cold foods may encourage diarrhea
  • Avoid foods and products that can aggravate diarrhea:
    • Milk and dairy foods, such as ice cream, sour cream, and cheese
    • Spicy foods, such as hot sauce, salsa, chili, and curry dishes
    • Foods or drinks with caffeine, such as regular coffee, black tea, soda, and chocolate
    • Foods or drinks that cause gas, such as cooked dried beans, cabbage, broccoli, soy milk, and other soy products
    • Foods that are high in fiber, such as raw fruits and vegetables, cooked dried beans, and whole wheat breads and cereals
    • Fried, high fat or greasy foods such as: pizza, fried meats, bacon, French fries, mayonnaise, cheese, rich desserts, cakes, cupcakes, donuts, cookies, pastries, potato chips, gravy, and butter
    • Food from fast food restaurants
    • Sugar free food, gum, and candy, which contain sugar alcohols such as sorbitol
    • Fiber supplements
    • Alcohol and smoking
  • Lie down after eating
  • Implement rectal skin care routine:
    • Clean area well with mild soap and water or aloe-based baby wipes
    • Use baby wipe or water from a spray bottle instead of toilet paperto clean after bowel movement OR
    • Use non-perfumed body lotion on toilet paper to clean area
    • Sitzbaths may add comfort (sitting in a tub of warm water)
    • Examine rectal area for red, scaly, or broken skin àreport to physician if present

content.title: Loss of Appetite
content.description:
General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Take frequent rest periods, before and after meals
  • Arrange for help in getting and preparing meals
  • Practicing relaxation exercises 30 minutes before meals to decrease stress
  • Eating high calorie, high protein foods
  • Eating several small meals every 2-3 hours with 1/3 of calories eaten at breakfast
  • Cold foods, such as vitamin-enhanced smoothies, sandwiches, yogurt
  • Add protein supplements or powered milk to casseroles, smoothies, etc.
  • Supplements such as Ensure or ProSure, two cans per day
  • Eating the most when hungriest, regardless of time of day
  • Reduce unpleasant environmental smells (such as cooking odors)
  • Record daily weight using same scale and report continued weight loss to physician
  • If loss of appetite continues, ask your physician for a prescription to help your appetite

content.title: Nausea/Vomiting
content.description:
Call physician immediately for:

  • Nausea and/or vomiting that is not relieved by physician recommendations and ordered drugs that have been taken as directed OR
  • Nausea causing not enough calories to be eaten or not enough fluids to be taken OR
  • Vomiting than does not allow you to take medicine or keep the medicine down OR
  • Vomiting more than 6 separate times (separated by 5 minutes) in 24 hours OR
  • Signs of dehydration even after you follow the management recommendations on the next page and follow doctor’s orders
    • Signs of dehydration include increased thirst, dry mouth, swollen tongue, weakness, dizziness, decreased urine output, fever, palpitations, confusion, fainting 

General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Monitor temperature daily and call physician for fever greater than 100.4 F (38 C)
  • Wait at least one hour following treatment to eat or drink anything
  • Encourage fluid intake to prevent dehydration (clear fluids such as ginger ale, apple juice, water, broth), popsicles, sherbet, juices low in acid (i.e., apple, pear, peach)
  • Ice chips at any time to keep hydrated
  • Sit upright during meals
  • Eat/drink slowly
  • Have small, frequent meals throughout day
  • Suggest bland foods such as soda crackers, dry toast; soft foods (i.e., eggs, mashed potatoes, mashed vegetables, creamed soups, puddings, custards, noodles, pastas and soft cheeses)
  • Increase intake of high protein beverages (i.e., milk shakes, instant breakfast mixes)
  • Avoid sweet, fried, fatty foods and those with strong odors (just the smell of food can trigger nausea and vomiting)
  • Avoid hard or crunchy foods as popcorn, nuts, raw vegetables
  • Avoid cigarettes or alcohol
  • Eating food cold or at room temperature can reduce strong smells
  • Avoid foods with strong smells such as coffee, onions, garlic, and foods that are being cooked
  • If foods have a metal taste, use plastic forks/spoons
  • Do not lie down after eating for at least 1-2 hours
  • Create a comfortable environment during eating, enjoy fresh air, wear loose-fitting clothing, keep distracted with something pleasant
  • Guided imagery, music therapy, and relaxation techniques may be effective
  • Use good mouth care: rinse mouth often to keep it clean and remove any bad taste or odors
  • Suck on sugar-free mints to rid bad taste

If nauseated in early morning, try snacking on crackers or toast before getting out of bed

content.description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that you wear disposable gloves when cleaning up diarrhea or other body fluids.

content.title: Mucositis
content.description:
Call physician immediately for any of the following:

  • Painful redness, swelling or ulcers in the mouth or throat that make swallowing and adequate fluid and food intake difficult
  • White patches or sticky white film in the mouth
  • Pain not relieved by acetaminophen, ordered pain relievers, topic medications (applied to the tissue inside the mouth), coating agents or cold therapy
  • Foul odor coming from mouth
  • Signs of dehydration even after you follow the management recommendations on the next page and follow doctor’s orders
    • Signs of dehydration are - increased thirst, dry mouth, swollen tongue, weakness, dizziness, decreased urine output, fever, palpitations, confusion, fainting
  • Symptoms getting worse even though you are following all recommendations

General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Monitor temperature daily and call physician for fever greater than 100.4 F (38 C)
  • Perform good cleaning of mouth and teeth after each meal and at bedtime, try Biotene toothpaste, soft nylon-bristled toothbrush (replaced regularly)
  • Do not use of foam-swabs to clean teeth as these can irritate and damage the surrounding tissues
  • Use a bland, non-alcohol-based mouth rinses before and after meals. Some suggestions are:
    • Normal saline (1 tsp of table salt to 32oz. water)
    • Bicarbonate rinses (½ tsp. baking soda dissolved in 2 cups of water)
    • Normal saline/sodium bicarbonate solution (1-2 tbsp of sodium bicarbonate to 1-quart normal saline) – especially helpful if viscous saliva is present
    • Acceptable mouth washes include Biotene dry mouth mouthwash, Biotene PBF, SmartMouth and Oasis
    • Any of the above solutions can be used at room or refrigerated temperatures. The technique should be rinse and swish 1-2 tbsp of solution, followed by spitting it out; repeated as often as necessary to maintain oral comfort
    • Frequent rinsing cleans and lubricates tissues, prevents crusting, and eases painful gums and mucus membranes
  • Lip care 2 x day with lanolin (Lansinoh or other lanolin), USP ointment or Aloe Vesta (Convatec) skin protectant or Radiablock lip balm, Biotene lip moisturizer gel, Aquaphor or Eucerin
  • Do not use known irritants such as:
    • Tobacco (smoking and chewing), alcohol, alcohol-based mouth washes, alcohol-based liquid
    • Chewable or alcohol-based liquid vitamins
  • Avoid ChapStick, occlusive lip balms such as petroleum
  • Oral use of cold therapy
    • Ice chips immediately prior to chemo and immediately after chemo for 30 minutes
    • For members under treatment with 5-FU, cold therapy may prevent oral mucositis if ice-chips are swished in their mouths for 30 minutes, beginning 5 minutes before 5-FU is administered.
    • Anytime to provide relief from discomfort
  • Denture care
    • Clean dentures with denture or toothbrush and regular toothpaste after meals and at bedtime
    • Clean denture storage container at least once a week
    • Wear dentures only when eating foods that require chewing if they are irritating the tissue in your mouth
    • Avoid use of dentures if mouth sores are present under them
    • Do NOT use denture adhesives
    • Do NOT wear loose dentures 
  • Topical anesthetics:
    • Often a coating agent and an anesthetic (pain killer) are combined as a 'magic mouthwash'
    • Irrigation/rinses should be used before using topical medication as removal of debris and saliva allows for better coating of tissues of the mouth/throat and prevents material from accumulating
    • Topical anesthetics have a limited duration of effect (15-30 minutes), may sting at first with application but should provide some relief
    • Physician may recommend application of topical Doxepin rinses which produces pain relief for 4 hours or longer and does not burn on application
    • If the topical anesthetic prescribed/recommended by physician is not effective à call the physician and ask for another
  • Mucosal coating agents:
    • Physician may order one item such as: Antacid (Maalox) – swished and swallowed, Amphojel, Kaopectate, Hydroxypropyl methylcellulose film-forming agents (e.g., Zilactin), Gelclair, for direct application to effected mucosa
    • Or physician may order combinations of topical anesthetics and coating agents
  • Psychological approaches to pain/discomfort:
    • Distraction
    • Relaxation/imagery
    • Cognitive/behavioral therapy
    • Music therapy

content.title: Helping someone eat: How can you help prepare for a meal?
content.description: Before the meal, there may be some things you can do ahead of time that will make it easier for your loved one to eat.

content.title: How can you help someone eat during a meal?
content.description: When you help someone eat, it helps to let them know how you plan to help throughout the meal.

content.title: Numbness/Pain of Hands or Feet
content.description:
Call physician immediately for any of the following in the hands or feet:

  • Numbness and/or tingling that does not improve before your next chemo treatment
  • Numbness and/or tingling that gets worse between chemo treatments or that is associated with pain
  • Weakness
  • Pain in the hands and/or feet not relieved by medication
  • Cold feet
  • Burning, tickling, pricking
  • Redness, warmth
  • Blistering or peeling
  • Being clumsy – for example, dropping things or needing help with buttoning a shirt or blouse when no help was needed before
  • Poor balance when walking
  • If you develop a fever (temperature above 100.4 F)

General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Check your hands and feet for sores or blisters
  • If you develop blisters, do not break them as they can become infected

Drugs/treatment changes or therapies that may be prescribed by your doctor:

  • Your physician will decide if the chemotherapy treatments need to be interrupted or the dose adjusted to prevent worsening of this side effect
  • Over the counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol®) may be helpful to relieve discomfort, but check with your doctor before taking

Protection and Safety:

  • Protect areas where sensation is decreased. (Example; do not walk around without footwear.) Wear thick socks and soft soled shoes
  • Extreme temperature changes may make symptoms worse
  • Wear warm clothing in cold weather and protect feet and hands from extreme cold
  • Use care when washing dishes or taking a bath or shower. Do not let the water get too hot
  • Avoid long exposure of hands and feet to hot water such as washing dishes, long showers, or tub baths
  • Short showers in tepid (lukewarm) water are recommended
  • Carefully pat your skin dry after washing or bathing, try not to rub your skin with a towel
  • Dishwashing gloves should not be worn, as the rubber will hold heat against your palms
  • Use potholders when cooking
  • Avoid skin contact with harsh chemicals used in laundry detergents or household cleaning products
  • Inspect skin for cuts, abrasions, burns daily, especially arms, legs, toes and fingers
  • Lower the temperature on your home water heater to avoid burns, and use a thermometer to make sure the water in your tub or shower is 120°F or less
  • Watch for unsafe situations when you are walking:
    • Remove unsafe things from your home, such as throw rugs or clutter on the floor
    • Use skid-free shower and bathroom mats
    • Use a cane or walker if needed to provide extra balance and security
  • Avoid increased pressure on the soles of the feet or palms of hands
  • Avoid tight fitting clothing (socks, stockings) or tight shoes. Wear loose, comfy shoes when going out and slippers around the house, do not go barefoot
  • Wear loose fitting, well-ventilated (air moves through easily) shoes and clothes
  • No jogging, aerobics, power walking, jumping -- avoid long days of walking
  • You should also avoid using garden tools, household tools such as screwdrivers, and other tasks where you are squeezing your hand on a hard surface
  • Using knives to chop food may also cause excessive pressure and friction on your palms
  • Avoid sun exposure as your skin is very sensitive to the sun while on treatment:
    • Remember, you get sun exposure just sitting in a sunny window!
    • Wear SPF 30 or higher daily or wear long sleeved shirts and pants

Comfort measures:

  • Cold may provide temporary relief for pain and tenderness
  • Placing the palms or bottoms of your feet on an ice pack or a bag of frozen peas may be very comforting. Alternate on and off for 15-20 minutes at a time.
    • Do not use for longer periods
    • Avoid applying ice (or ice packs) directly to the skin
  • Lotions such as Aveeno®, Lubriderm®, Udder Cream®, Eucerin, and Bag Balm® provide excellent moisturizing to your hands and feet
  • Keeping palms and soles moist is very important between chemo treatments
  • Apply a moisturizer to your hands and feet liberally and often, but gently to avoid rubbing the skin too strongly. Try applying a generous amount of moisturizer at bedtime and wear a loose pair of cotton gloves or socks to bed to promote absorption of the lotion.
  • Avoid any lotions or creams that contain perfumes, alcohol or glycerin
  • Elevate your hands and feet when sitting or lying down, this may help decrease swelling

Therapies: 

  • If you experience weakness or poor balance when walking, ask your physician if:
    • physical therapy may be beneficial and/or
    • supportive devices to help with gait stability and/or
    • occupational therapy to help with assistive devices for activities of daily living

content.title: Caregiving: Helping Someone Get In and Out of a Car
Pain
content.description:
Call physician immediately for:

  • Pain or breakthrough pain not improved in 24 hours after you have followed the physician recommendations and taken your drugs for pain as they were ordered AND
  • Pain is disabling OR
  • Pain or medication is interfering with sleep or activities of daily living OR
  • Increased problem with swallowing, breathing, swelling of tongue OR
  • Sudden sharp pain that happens along with problem walking or moving a leg OR
  • Other problems such as a rash, nausea and vomiting from pain medications, sleepiness causing you to not eat, drink, walk OR
  • Pain with drainage, swelling, redness, warmth or fever

General helpful suggestions and interventions:

  • Take acetaminophen, aspirin, or ibuprofen for mild pain as recommended by physician

  • Take prescription analgesics (pain killers) as prescribed
    • Most prescriptions for cancer pain will be on a fixed schedule for long acting medication with short acting for breakthrough pain
    • Additionally, other prescriptions will be provided to control pain that occurs between the scheduled doses (breakthrough pain) to be taken as needed along with the regular fixed-schedule pain medication
    • The amount of time between doses depends on which pain med was prescribed
    • The physician will attempt to prescribe the dose that controls pain with the fewest side effects
    • The goal is to achieve a good balance between pain relief and side effects by gradually adjusting the dose

  • It is important to use the breakthrough pain medication as ordered
    • Try to anticipate painful activities and take medication 30 minutes ahead

  • Keep a pain diary to show/report to physician including description of the pain, character, severity and location as well as:
    • Interventions taken
    • Non-pharmacologic interventions and pain medications taken
    • Evaluation of response to interventions

  • Keep up your activity the best you can

  • Since pain medications may cause constipation, follow the recommendations below to prevent constipation:
    • Take stool-softeners/laxatives as recommended/prescribed; call the physician for a prescription for stool-softeners/laxatives if not already provided
    • It is important to take these routinely as ordered and not wait until symptoms of constipation are present
    • Drink 8-10 ounces of liquids daily; carry a bottle to sip from throughout the day; water, juice, soup and soft drinks are good choices; limit coffee and tea as they cause water loss
    • Natural laxatives such as prunes/prune juice or papayas may help
    • Engage in activity such as walking and exercise (if possible)
    • Establish a regular time for daily bowel movement; after breakfast is ideal
    • Drink hot beverages 30 minutes before regular time for bowel movements
    • Include high-fiber foods in daily diet, such as wheat bran, whole-grain breads, oatmeal, peanut butter, beans, fruits, and vegetables

  • Complimentary therapies: Physical therapy and involving the body/mind in other activities may help reduce pain
    • Heat and Cold – hot packs, heating pads, baths or crushed ice in a plastic bag or flexible cold packs wrapped in a towel may have a short-term effect in reducing some types of pain
    • Relaxation techniques – may be used for episodes of brief pain (for example, during cancer treatment procedures). Brief, simple techniques are suitable for periods when your ability to concentrate is limited by severe pain, high anxiety, or fatigue (think of somewhere beautiful you would like to be)
    • Distraction techniques – listening to books on tape, watching TV, reading, doing crafts, reading jokes, listening to music, especially from your own collection
    • Imagery – thinking of somewhere beautiful, audio or video tapes of pleasant or soothing scenes or experiences
    • Breathing techniques - Breathing in and out slowly and regularly at a comfortable rate, while keeping stomach and shoulders relaxed
    • Massage – from simple hand holding and stroking to shoulder, back and/or hand and feet massage
    • Light exercise – range of motion, stretching
    • Prayer/Meditation
    • Acupuncture
    • Hypnosis

content.title: 6 Things to Do Every Day If You Have Prediabetes
content.description:
According to the American Diabetes Association, 96 million Americans 18 years and older had prediabetes in 2019. But having prediabetes doesn’t mean you’ll develop type 2 diabetes, especially if you follow a treatment plan and make healthy lifestyle choices. For some folks with prediabetes, moderate lifestyle changes can actually bring blood sugar levels back to a normal range, which can help prevent or delay the onset of type 2 diabetes. Below are six healthy habits you can do daily that are recommended by registered dietitian nutritionists (RDNs) who specialize in prediabetes.

1. Fill half (or more) of your plate with fruits and vegetables.

According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, only 1 in 10 Americans consume the recommended five to nine servings of fruits and veggies per day. These foods are brimming with nutrients and fiber and are lower in calories. Plus, according to Lauren Harris-Pincus, M.S., RDN, founder of NutritionStarringYOU.com and author of The Everything Easy Pre-Diabetes Cookbook, "The antioxidants and phytochemicals in fruits and veggies can play a role in improving insulin resistance, which can help to better control blood sugar.” Filling your plate at least half full of them at each meal or snack is a great way to make sure you’re meeting your needs.

“Once you do this, you’ll find you’ll never be hungry eating moderate-sized portions of starchy foods and protein-rich foods,” says Jill Weisenberger, M.S., RDN, CDCES, CHWC, FAND, creator of the free guide Can I Eat That with Prediabetes? “The non-starchy vegetables are low-calorie, low-carb, and very filling. Plus, they’re jam-packed with health-boosting phytonutrients that act as antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds.”

2. Manage your stress.

Harris-Pincus explains, “Chronic stress can wreak havoc on health and well-being by hindering your immunity, making you susceptible to many types of illnesses. Plus, stress hormones like cortisol can contribute to weight gain and elevated blood sugar.” She suggests adding stretching exercises, meditation, or deep breathing exercises to your daily routine: “Make time for self-care by choosing a relaxing activity you enjoy—preferably off of screens, like knitting, painting, word puzzles, listening to music, or reading a good book.”

3. Get your sleep.

Did you know that not getting enough sleep not only makes you cranky, but also makes you less likely to stick to your healthy-eating goals? In addition, Weisenberger says it actually messes with your body’s response to insulin. “Short-sleeping changes levels of growth hormone and cortisol, which makes us more insulin-resistant. Even a single night of lousy sleep can make you more insulin-resistant the following day." According to the CDC, adults should aim for seven hours of sleep per night.

4. Avoid binge drinking.

According to Lorena Drago, M.S., RDN, CDN, CDCES, a certified diabetes care and education specialist, binge drinking is defined as “four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men in about two hours, which can increase your risk of type 2 diabetes.” Binge drinking can cause the pancreas to become inflamed and unable to secrete insulin as a result of excessive alcohol consumption. If you choose to drink alcohol, the recommendation is no more than one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men. One drink is defined as 12 fluid ounces of beer, 5 fluid ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of 80-proof liquor like rum or vodka.

5. Get moving.

“Prolonged sitting, including spending many hours watching television or in front of a computer, may accelerate your risk of developing type 2 diabetes,” Drago explains. “Lack of exercise is a major contributor to chronic disease. Physical activity enhances insulin sensitivity, increases how the muscles use blood glucose (sugar), and improves insulin resistance.” Drago recommends doing at least 30 minutes of physical activity five days a week. To help you stick with it, pick a type of movement you really enjoy instead of trying to force yourself to do something you don’t like. That could be yoga, dancing, lifting weights, swimming, cycling, running, or more.

6. Follow a plant-based diet.

“Powerful plant-based foods like nuts, seeds, fruit, vegetables, whole grains, beans, and legumes contain disease-fighting nutrients that can reduce your risk for heart disease, lower your cholesterol, help manage your blood sugar, and improve your mood,” says Toby Smithson, RDN, LD, CDCES, FAND, a diabetes lifestyle expert and founder of DiabetesEveryDay.com and author of Diabetes Meal Planning and Nutrition for Dummies. “A plant-based diet is effective in lowering the risk of developing type 2 diabetes because it is higher in fiber, lower in saturated fat, and improves insulin sensitivity. Proof is in the pudding, as long as your pudding is plant-based. The research shows this type of eating pattern is associated with a 30% reduction in diabetes risk.”

content.title: How Exercise Can Help When You Have Diabetes
content.description:
Ever wonder exactly what happens in your body when you exercise? Wonder no more. Here’s what happens before, during, and after exercise.

Before exercise

At rest, two hormones from your pancreas—insulin and glucagon—play opposing roles to keep your blood sugar stable: Insulin moves sugar into your cells and glucagon shuttles sugar out of cells. After you eat, sugar and other nutrients are released into your blood from your intestines. Insulin levels rise to move that sugar into your cells, including muscle and liver cells, to be used or stored. Between meals, glucagon levels rise to maintain your blood sugar by releasing that stored glucose back into your bloodstream—preventing low blood sugar.

During exercise

The Warmup

It’s time to get your heart pumping. As you start to move, your muscles use their own stored sugar as well as sugar from the bloodstream to make an energy compound (called ATP) that helps them contract. And soon your hungry muscles need more sugar to make that fuel. So your body gradually lowers insulin levels and raises glucagon levels to release more stored sugar (from your liver) into your bloodstream for muscles to use.

At rest, muscles require insulin to absorb glucose, so how does that released sugar enter active muscle cells with only a small amount of insulin? First, working muscles place more transporters on the surface of their cells that act like doors for insulin to deposit sugar into. The more doors, the more sensitive cells are to insulin, even with less of it floating around. And second, active muscles can also absorb glucose on their own without insulin, so less insulin is needed. Both pathways prompt muscles to absorb excess glucose, helping to lower high blood sugar.

The Workout

Now you’re in the swing of your activity, be it dancing, walking, swimming, or a body-weight circuit. To keep your muscles happy, your body releases other hormones, like adrenaline, that free even more stored glucose from the liver. How much sugar is released depends on how long and how hard you go.

During intense activities (think: short sprints with little downtime, or a hard lifting session), adrenaline may release more sugar than your muscles can use, which can raise blood sugar for up to two hours post-exercise. This temporary spike is common and typically does not impact your A1C, though it may need to be balanced through food or medicine post-workout.

After exercise

While you cool down, catch your breath, and sip water, your muscles and liver are still hard at work absorbing sugar out of the blood to replenish their stores for next time. And those good effects that happened during exercise—improved insulin action and sensitivity—may remain enhanced for up to 48 hours post-sweat.

Heart-pumping aerobic activities aren’t the only form of exercise that's beneficial: Resistance training can also increase glucose uptake and reduce insulin resistance. That’s why combo workouts (think: water aerobics, body-weight circuits, or even walk-then-lift sessions) may be the most effective for blood glucose management.

Working out with insulin

How muscles use glucose during exercise is the same for all people. But people who have type 1 diabetes, and those who take insulin, often need to take extra steps to avoid blood sugar swings and lows during activity. This may mean adjusting insulin dosages or eating a source of glucose before or during exercise. If blood sugar levels rise after a hard effort, it may seem intuitive to treat raised levels with an insulin dose, but this rise is temporary and taking insulin could increase the risk for a delayed low.

Navigating your body’s response to physical activity when on insulin can be frustrating, but finding a regular exercise routine that works for you is possible. Have patience with yourself and take the necessary precautions: Check your blood sugar before working out, pack a source of glucose, and listen to your body.

content.title: Food Safety 101 for Cancer Patients
content.description:
Cancer and its treatment can weaken the immune system. So, when cooking for yourself or someone else with cancer, it’s critical to practice good food-safety habits. Here’s a quick review of the basics. 

Keep it clean.

Before cooking, wash your hands and prep surfaces with warm or hot soapy water. If produce will be eaten raw, wash it thoroughly first—even prewashed salad greens—with plenty of cold running water. Use a vegetable brush to scrub produce that won’t be peeled.

Keep them separate.

To avoid cross-contamination with disease-causing bacteria, keep cutting boards and prep areas for raw meats, poultry, fish, and eggs separate from the ones you use to prepare cooked foods or vegetables, salads, and other dishes meant to be eaten raw.

Hold it safely.

If you’re not serving food right away, keep it at a safe temperature, but for no more than two hours. Hot food should be at or above 140°F; cold food below 40°F. If you have a hot dish you’re planning to deliver later, chill it first. Divide it into smaller, shallow containers or place it on ice or in a cold-water bath to cool quickly. Put it in the fridge when it reaches 140°F.

Send it safely.

Bringing a meal to someone? Pack it in an insulated container and make sure someone is there to receive it and refrigerate it right away. If that’s not possible, use a cooler with at least two ice packs. Again, do not leave anything at room temperature for more than 2 hours.

Watch the temps.

Use a food thermometer to ensure foods are fully cooked. That's especially important when you're heating or reheating food in the microwave, which can have hot and cold spots. Measure temperature in the center or in the thickest part of the food.

Safe Cooking Temperatures

The USDA recommends cooking these foods to the following minimum internal temperatures. While the guidelines apply to everyone, they’re especially important for people with cancer, as some treatments can weaken the body’s ability to fight off infection. Use an instant-read thermometer to confirm.

  • Ground meats: 160°F
  • All poultry (parts, whole, ground): 165°F
  • Fish and shellfish: 145°F, or until flesh is opaque or shells open.
  • Steaks, roasts, and chops: 145°F
  • Casseroles and leftovers: 165°F
  • Eggs and egg dishes: Cook until firm or to 160°F.

content.title: Why Support Helps When You Have Breast Cancer
content.description:
Experts agree that breast cancer is a disease best fought with a team—a team that includes health-care professionals, family, and friends. Women can be especially bad about asking for help, perhaps because they're so used to taking care of other people. But this is no time to be stoic or polite.

Friends and family

"You're not Wonder Woman and you can't do everything—and that's OK," says Karen R. Monaghan, LICSW, a clinical oncology social worker at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. "It's hard for people to say, 'I need someone to clean my bathroom.' But don't be afraid to reach out."

When you organize your cancer-fighting team, whether formally or in the natural course of things in your family or community, let someone else be the point person, the one others can call to check on how you're doing and see where they can help. Or put that information online at CaringBridge.org.

Providers

Being able to reach out to your medical team is just as important. You have to be able to speak freely with the key people fighting to make you well, and you should understand what they're asking you to do and why. If you have questions, keep asking them until the answers make sense.

If doctor-patient communication is not as open and effective as you'd like, change that. "You have to be able to communicate with your oncologist," stresses Pam T., 54, of Seattle. "If you don't like [your doctor], then you need to get another one. This is too serious a matter to not be understanding what they're saying to you."
content.copyright: © Meredith Operations Corporation. All rights reserved. Used with permission.

content.title: Working Out but Not Losing Weight? Here's Why
content.description:
Do you eat well, exercise often and still feel like you’re not maintaining a healthy weight? Truth is, eating well and exercising often are very relative and general statements. If we’re honest with ourselves, we might all admit that we’re capable of trying a little harder in both areas.

Total-body wellness is a lifestyle. Fat loss happens when you ditch the scale, find an activity you enjoy and start to see food as fuel instead of something to feed your emotions or occupy your time.

No matter who you are or what your background is, chances are one of these six reasons could be why you’re not shedding pounds.

1. You’re not eating the good stuff.

If you’re working out but not losing weight, the first place you should be looking is the kitchen. Some people focus so much energy on burning off calories that they don’t take the time to consider what they’re putting in as fuel. A good rule of thumb is to stick to all-natural, whole foods.

Tip: Look for foods that have the fewest ingredients on the label, if you can’t pronounce it, it’s probably not something you want to be putting in your body. 

2. You’re doing too much cardio.

Yes, cardio is a necessary part of your workout routine. It keeps your heart healthy, boosts your metabolism and gives you a good sweat.

However, only doing cardio (or doing too much of it) can add to the problem. Longer cardio sessions, like staying on the elliptical for 90 minutes or going for regular 10-mile runs, can eat away at your lean muscle mass, which is essential for increasing your metabolism to burn more calories. It causes the body to become more endurance-focused, storing energy as fat to ensure it has plenty of reserve fuel to keep you going for all those miles. Not to mention it dramatically increases your appetite, making you more susceptible to unnecessary snacking or overeating.

Tip: Federal guidelines for physical activity suggest that adults also do strength training, focusing on all major muscle groups, two or more days a week.

3. You’re not lifting weights.

If you love to run or bike for reasons other than losing weight, then by all means don’t stop. But if you’re working out but not losing weight, and your primary goal is fat loss, there are other forms of exercise that give a much better bang for your buck. The best way to lose weight and build lean muscle is by doing some form of strength training in addition to your cardio. The more muscle tone your body has, the more fat you’ll burn.

If you’re not ready to give up your cardio routine just yet, try adding some interval training by performing short bursts of all-out effort mixed into your regular session. These workouts are much more effective at promoting hormones that target stubborn fat. Then, start adding some resistance training to your routine.

Tip: Body-weight exercises like push-ups, squats, and lunges are a great place to start to help build up to lifting actual weights.

4. You’re not working hard enough.

There’s no exact equation to working out and eating healthy—it’s a matter of trial and error, finding out what works specifically for your body. And more time spent in the gym doesn’t always equal a more fit person. Your workouts should be intensity-dependent, not time-dependent. Keep this fact in mind: the harder you work, the shorter your workout time may need to be.

Tip: Maximize time spent at the gym, in fitness class, or in your at-home workout routine so you can achieve that coveted after-burn effect, which keeps your metabolism revved for 24 to 48 hours afterward.

5. You’re not taking time to recover.

Recovery and rest are often more important than the workout itself. It’s during those periods that your body does most of the actual fat burning.

Tip: Give yourself time to fully recover so you’re ready to work hard the following day. Most importantly, listen to your body. Push yourself, but give it some love, too.

6. You’ve plateaued.

You’re exercising regularly and eating healthfully, but now the numbers on the scale won’t budge; your weight loss has plateaued. There are lots of reasons this can happen, says the Mayo Clinic. If you’re cutting calories, you may experience a rapid drop in weight initially, as your body burns stored glycogen for energy. You might even lose a little muscle along with fat. To rev up your weight loss again, you may need to cut more calories or amp up your physical activity.

Tip: Add resistance training to build muscle and burn fat.

content.title: Sleep Might Be the Reason You’re Not Losing Weight
content.description:
A solid night of shut-eye is so crucial for our body and mind, yet most of us don’t get what we truly need. Many Americans report sleeping only about seven hours a night, and lots of us log even fewer hours, which is when it becomes unhealthy.

“Adequate sleep helps to allow your body to perform all the regulatory and maintenance functions it needs to function properly. Healthy sleep also helps set the stage for many domains of health,” says Michael A. Grandner, Ph.D., M.T.R., director of the Sleep and Health Research Program at the University of Arizona College of Medicine.

A recently published research review, which Grandner authored, shows that insufficient sleep can shorten your lifespan, stoke inflammation, raise your risk of diabetes and heart disease, and negatively affect your mental health.

But what about your weight? Does sleep play a role in the number we see on the scale? We dug into the science.

Does sleep influence your appetite?

When we fall short on sleep, research shows our levels of ghrelin (the hormone that makes us feel hungry) go up, and our levels of leptin (the hormone that helps us to feel full) dip, explains Grandner. Also, when leptin levels rise—which appears to happen during sleep—it counter-regulates ghrelin and has the potential to tamp down your hunger.

Falling short on sleep also disrupts how your body regulates insulin and glucose, as well as other substances in the body that regulate hunger and appetite.

Can sleep help or hinder your weight-loss goals?

Skimping on shut-eye has the potential to make losing weight that much harder. Here’s why: “Not only does lack of sleep disrupt hormones that regulate hunger and appetite, it also leads to increased eating of unhealthy foods at night, decreases energy level which leads to craving energy [aka food], and even impairs brain function, which makes it harder to make healthy choices,” explains Grandner.

Take a look at the research on the topic and you’ll see that there is a connection between sleep and body weight. Research shows that folks who consistently fall short on sleep weigh more over time than their counterparts who get adequate sleep. Other studies have found that dieters who lose even just a little bit of sleep aren’t as successful at losing weight compared to dieters who log enough zzz’s. For instance, one study, published in Sleep, put one group of adults on a calorie-restricted diet and told them to cut out about one hour of sleep five days a week (the other two days they could sleep as much as they wanted). Another group went on the same calorie-restricted diet. The findings? Compared to the dieters who didn’t limit their sleep, the sleep- deprived group lost less body fat. Both groups, however, lost about the same amount of total body weight.

All of this said, there are some studies that suggest the impact of sleep on weight isn’t all that significant (statistically speaking, too). And then there’s research that found men to be more likely than women to pack on the extra pounds when their sleep is lacking.

So, how many hours of sleep should you aim for?

Is there a magic number you need to get to best support your diet and meet your weight-loss goals? “Most of the evidence shows that most adults need at least seven hours of sleep on a typical night, and probably not more than nine hours,” advises Grandner. (There is some evidence that too much sleep can have a similar effect on your weight as too little sleep.) “And this recommendation is echoed by most major medical and scientific authorities, based on over 50 years of scientific data.”

content.title: 5 Ways Screen Time Can Benefit Families
content.description:
The dangers of screen time are well-documented and well-known; i.e., too much screen time can cause developmental delays or have social implications or both. Behavioral problems may also arise, particularly in children who spend two hours a day (or more) on the TV, computer, tablet, or phone. And there are physical effects, too. Too much screen time can lead to eye strain, pain, and childhood obesity. In short, there are inherent risks. But there are benefits as well. Yes, screen time can actually be a good thing.

According to an October 2019 study out of Oxford, Cardiff, and Cambridge universities, screen time in moderation can have a positive effect on kids. Watching television or using digital devices can increase one’s social and emotional well-being.

“In light of our findings, calls for blanket technology bans and age restrictions on technology access do not constitute evidence-based or indeed ethical advice, particularly as screen usage in some cases has a net positive impact,” said Professor Andrew Przybylski, director of research at the Oxford Internet Institute, in a release. What’s more, a July 2020 report, from the nonprofit Common Sense Media, suggested that parents should focus more on what their kids are consuming and less on how many hours they’re logging.

“All screen use is not equal,” Michael Robb, an author of the report and senior director of research at Common Sense Media, told CNN. This became particularly apparent in the height of the pandemic, when children were using computers to attend class and interacting with their peers. Below are five benefits of screen time.

1. Improves socialization

While it may seem counterintuitive, screen time can improve your child’s social and emotional well-being. According to Internet Matters, “Technology takes away physical barriers to social connections—which is important for children who find it hard to make friends or have special interests or special needs.” It can be used for both conversations and play. Many kids video-called their friends in early 2020, when lockdowns forced them to stay home. They held tea parties and playdates over the web. And social media platforms can foster a sense of community and connectedness.

2. Enhances critical thinking

Not all apps and video games are created equal. That’s a fact. But did you know some may encourage learning and enhance critical thinking skills? “A lot of these games won’t even feel like learning,” says Caroline Knorr, senior parenting editor at Common Sense Media. “But parents know time playing is time well spent with puzzles and games that challenge kids to experiment and find creative ways to solve problems.”

3. Promotes school readiness

From educational games and apps to digital books, or e-books, screens can promote school readiness. Some television programs even encourage reading, spelling, math skills, and writing. And while the American Academy of Pediatrics does not recommend screen usage for children under 18 months, high-quality apps and programs can be a great learning tool for kids older than that. Co-play with your toddlers because that's how they learn best.

4. Helps development of fine motor skills

Working on computers and playing video games can help your child improve their hand-eye coordination, Internet Matters explains. Interacting with computers improves both visual intelligence and hand-eye coordination,” the website states. It also affects their coordination.

“Playing video games can improve motor skills,” Nemours Children’s Health adds.

5. Encourages literacy and communication

While it may seem odd to suggest that screens can (and do) improve literacy and communication skills, it’s true. E-books improve our reading proficiency. They also give us access to a wide and varied library, larger than most people could have in their home. Texting can help kids learn to read and spell. And various apps and computer programs encourage communication, from emails and notes to messaging, Word and Google Docs.

That said, it’s still important to balance time in front of the computer with other activities. Sitting in front of the TV or staring at your phone all the time is not good or healthy. It can have adverse effects. So, what exactly can parents do to ensure their kids are consuming quality content? Be involved, be aware of how your children are engaging with digital media, and try to help your kids find a balance of online and offline activities. Experts recommend following the “Three C’s”: Child, content, and context. That is, you know what’s best for your child, but you can also try to help them prioritize quality content.

content.title: How to Teach Kids to Swim at Every Age
content.description:
Tempted to sign your little one up for swimming lessons this summer? That’s a smart move, considering that drowning is a top cause of death among children, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics.

“While no course can ‘drown-proof’ a child, a progressive learn-to-swim program can provide your child with skills that will last a lifetime,” says Connie Harvey, national health-and-safety expert for the American Red Cross.

Always take the time to research swim lessons before enrolling. Classes should focus on both swimming skills and “water survival competency skills,” says the AAP, and they should be taught by instructors certified through a nationally recognized learn-to-swim curriculum. “There should also be lifeguards on duty who have current CPR and First Aid certification,” adds the organization. What’s more, the lessons should be age-appropriate, and the water should be kept warm and clean.

Whether you enroll in swim lessons or take to the backyard pool, here’s how to teach a child to swim at every age.

1 to 2 years old

At this age, you simply want to introduce your child to the water. Play in the pool with them, or join a class that focuses on having fun and getting comfortable in the water (instead of learning to swim). Activities may include showing them how to splash, singing songs while bobbing around, and playing gentle games together.

Safety tips:

  • Keep your baby in your arms at all times.
  • Do not submerge any child under age 3. Kids this age can swallow a large amount of water, enough to dilute the chemicals in their blood, causing sleepiness, nausea, and seizures. In rare cases, water intoxication can be fatal.
  • An infant can drown in an inch or two of water in less than 30 seconds, so beware of all water hazards, including inflatable baby pools, buckets, toilets, and tubs.

2 to 3 years old

Wondering how to teach a toddler to swim? Your curious tot will be more active in the water now, though they still need an adult to hold them. In your pool or swimming program, play fun games that encourage them to move their arms, kick their legs, and float supported on their stomach or back.

Show them how to blow bubbles in the water so they learn to get their face wet without swallowing. By the time they’re 3, they may be able to do these things with little help from you.

Safety tips:

  • Your toddler may feel so comfortable in the water that they think they can swim solo. But don’t leave them alone. Even for a minute. They need constant adult supervision around water.
  • Stress basic pool safety, like not running near the pool and only going into the water with Mommy or Daddy.
  • Avoid water wings, air-filled swimsuits, and inflatable flotation toys. Your toddler will sink if they deflate, and these items can give them (and you) a false sense of security. 

4 to 5 years old

Now that your child is developing enough coordination to swim by themselves, they can enroll in formal swimming lessons. If they don’t have much experience in the water, choose a program that will help them get comfortable. You might be allowed to participate in their first class to make the transition easier.

In the shallow water, your child should learn how to float independently, submerge their head under the water for 5 to 10 seconds, go from a standing to a swimming position without assistance, glide through the water, reach an exit point, and use coordinated kicking and arm movements. Their swimming class should focus on both water and safety skills.

Safety tips:

  • Even though you don’t have to hold your child, a guardian should practice “reach supervision” by being in the water within reaching distance.
  • Be patient. Your child may be a fish one day and afraid of the water the next. Don’t force them to do an activity until they’re ready.
  • Never assume another adult is watching, even if a lifeguard is present.

6 years old and up

An older child can hold their breath for longer periods of time, swim underwater, and retrieve objects at the bottom. They’ll be able to jump into the water and resurface on their own. They can start learning all swimming strokes, including the breaststroke and backstroke. Their greater endurance will allow them to swim longer distances.

At this point, you don’t have to be in the water with your child, but you still need to supervise all pool activities because they may overestimate their own abilities.

Safety tips:

  • An adult should watch all water activities. Even a good swimmer can drown.
  • Make it a rule that your child can swim only with an adult present, and encourage them to always swim with a buddy.
  • You should be extra vigilant at the beach or a lake. A child’s swimming skills in a pool don’t necessarily translate to open water.

content.title: Secrets for a Healthy Early Pregnancy
content.description:
Pregnancy is supposed to be a joyful time, but for many women, the first trimester can be rough. Here are a few tips to help you get through the first months.

Look for relief from your nausea.

Morning sickness can be the roughest part of early pregnancy. But not all is lost. Many women find small lifestyle changes can make a big difference when it comes to vomiting and nausea. Some things to try: eating bland foods like saltines in the morning, before you even get out of bed; eating more frequent, smaller meals; snacking on ginger candies or sipping ginger soda; and avoiding offending smells. Although medical studies on acupuncture and morning sickness haven’t shown significant benefits, many women who’ve been through severe nausea and vomiting swear by it.

Try chewable prenatal vitamins.

Many women with morning sickness find that swallowing pills can be hard or trigger a gag reflex, but taking prenatal vitamins is key to making sure your developing fetus has the building blocks it needs. Thankfully, there are lots of chewable prenatal vitamins out there. Choose an iron-free formulation until your morning sickness passes, since iron can make nausea worse.

Keep moving.

Exercise is a pregnant woman’s best medicine. Regular exercise can help you sleep better so that you’re not so exhausted during the first trimester. Not only that, but regular activity can also help improve your mood and can help get you in condition for labor. Try to keep up with a regular routine, like going for a morning walk before work or taking a mid-day stroll with a coworker. If it’s been a while since you worked out, you can ease yourself into it, starting with about five minutes a day, until you can exercise for 30 minutes at a time. But first, make sure to get the green light from your doctor before starting or stepping up your fitness regime.

Floss away.

Clean teeth are more important than ever. Pregnancy hormones can make your gums temporarily swollen and sensitive. But that doesn’t mean you can postpone your regular twice-a-year professional cleanings, since the inflammation caused by gum disease has been linked to preterm birth. For the next nine months, make sure to brush twice a day and floss daily. Another tooth tip: Don’t brush your teeth right away if you vomit from morning sickness. The acids can harm your enamel. Instead, rinse with warm water and brush your tongue. You can go back and brush your teeth after about 10 minutes.

Make sure to put yourself first.

You might be tempted to focus all your attention on your growing baby, but it’s important to focus some attention on your own self-care, especially your emotional well-being. Pregnancy can be a stressful time for many moms-to-be. You’re learning about how to care for your new child, undergoing bodily changes, and having to rethink parts of your lifestyle. Make sure to take time each week for yourself, relax, take a long bath, and ask your partner to take on some chores while you put your feet up. Talk with your doctor about ways you can manage stress and be sure to speak up if you’re feeling anxious, worried, sad, or depressed.

content.title: Pregnancy Dos and Don’ts: Health and Exercise
content.description:
When you’re pregnant, you want to do everything you can to keep yourself and your baby as healthy as possible. Here, the dos and don’ts of exercise, health, and mental health during pregnancy.

Pregnancy Exercise

Exercise is not only safe during most pregnancies, but it also may ease many pregnancy discomforts and possibly shorten your labor and delivery and recovery time.

The Dos of Pregnancy Exercise

  • Exercise moderately for at least 30 minutes on most days, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends.

  • Stick with low-impact exercises such as walking, yoga, and swimming.

  • Stay cool and drink plenty of water. Dehydration can lead to overheating, which is dangerous for the fetus. Drink before, during, and after exercise.

  • Wear workout clothes that don’t constrict your rib cage as you breathe.

  • Stretch before and after exercise. Prenatal yoga is a great way to stay flexible and strong.

  • Build your strength. Focus on your back, shoulders, pectorals (chest), and biceps so they’ll keep you strong enough to pick up and hold your baby.

  • Do Kegel exercises daily to help prevent urinary incontinence. Repeatedly contract and relax your pelvic floor muscles as though you’re stopping and starting the flow of urine.

The Don’ts of Pregnancy Exercise

  • Don’t work out to the point of exhaustion. Make sure you can still carry on a conversation while you’re exercising.

  • Don’t keep exercising if you feel dizzy or lightheaded.

  • Don’t get overheated. Consider early-morning or evening walks or go to an air-conditioned gym.

  • Don’t lift heavy weights, lie on your stomach or back, or use machines that require wearing a belt around your waist.

  • Don’t tackle high-impact sports or activities in which you risk falling or injuring your abdomen, such as in-line skating, soccer, downhill skiing, and horseback riding.

  • Don’t exercise if you experience any of the following: an incompetent cervix; pregnancy with multiple risk factors for premature labor; persistent second- or third-trimester bleeding; placenta previa past 26 weeks; premature labor; ruptured membranes; or preeclampsia.

Staying Healthy

Expert prenatal care from a doctor or licensed midwife sets the stage for a healthy pregnancy and baby.

The Do’s of Pregnancy Health

  • Get a checkup as soon as you know you are pregnant. Regular weight, blood pressure, and fetal heart-rate checks will help detect any medical complications early.

  • Take care of your teeth. Mouth infections are linked to prematurity.

  • Take it easy at work. If you’re on your feet all day, look for ways to sit down as often as possible.

  • Seek treatment for other health conditions you may have. Left untreated, these may pose risks to your fetus.

  • Call your doctor or midwife immediately if you experience any of the following: calf pain or swelling; chest pain; decreased fetal movement; vaginal bleeding; labored breathing without exertion; dizziness; persistent headache; leakage of amniotic fluid; muscle weakness; uterine contractions, abdominal pain or increased pelvic pressure.

The Don’ts of Pregnancy Health

  • Don’t take any medication—prescription, over-the-counter, or herbal—without checking with your doctor or midwife.

  • Don’t take aspirin, ibuprofen or naproxen unless they’re prescribed by your doctor, as they may cause fetal bleeding. Acetaminophen is usually okay, but ask your doctor.

  • Don’t stop taking medication for a chronic condition such as asthma without checking with your doctor.

  • Don’t smoke or use any type of illicit drugs.

  • Don’t forget to wear gloves when changing the cat litter or gardening. Cat feces in litter or soil may transmit toxoplasmosis, which can cause neurological problems in your baby.

  • Don’t sit in hot tubs or saunas. Hot environments can raise your body temperature and interfere with fetal brain development.

  • Don’t handle oil-based paints or materials containing lead or mercury. Avoid chemical solvents, oven-cleaning products, and dry-cleaning chemicals.

Mental Health during Pregnancy

Stress can contribute to premature birth, low birth weight, and problems with fetal development. Signs that your stress level is too high include constant fatigue and worry, feeling out of control, and being overactive.

The Do’s of Pregnancy Mental Health

  • Learn relaxation techniques such as visualization and meditation. Spend 20 minutes a day breathing slowly and deeply, progressively relaxing all the muscles in your body.

  • Get enough sleep. Go to bed earlier, sleep later, or take a nap in the afternoon if you can. A body pillow may help you sleep better.

  • Lean on friends and family members as much as you need to. Social support is a great antidote to stress.

  • See your doctor if stress interferes with your ability to function.

The Don’ts of Pregnancy Mental Health

  • Don’t take on unnecessary stress such as changing jobs or buying a house, if at all possible.

  • Don’t worry too much about the pain of labor. Today, you have more natural and pharmaceutical pain-relief options than ever. Plus, millions of women make it through labor each year. If they can do it, so can you.

  • Don’t forget that this is one of the most exciting and rewarding times of your life, one that you will always remember. Enjoy!
